{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3174052,"name":"Benjamin Warwick","username":"beb","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/beb/{size}/171589_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-27T15:04:23.500Z","cooked":"

I got ROS to work in a Java WPILib environment!

Many teams including 88 have used NetworkTables to connect to ROS or another coprocessor. I know 900 has reformatted their rio to accommodate the full ros_comm installation. I’ve not heard teams trying the pure java implementation of ROS.

As a reminder, here’s what ROS can do for FIRST:

  • Enables neural nets that find game pieces (and field elements if trained for that):
    • Game objects: Labeled images for cones and cubes - #32 by beb
    • Everything on the field: Zebravision 7.0
  • LIDAR-based localization (good enough to shoot on the fly with the right weather): Using ROS for inspiration in FRC
  • Field simulation to deployment facilitated by ROS+Unity: FRC Robotics with ROS
  • Trajectory following: GitHub - frcteam195/swerve_trajectory_node: Generates trajectories for the robot to drive along. & 2022RobotCode/zebROS_ws/src/path_follower at master · FRC900/2022RobotCode · GitHub
  • Localization using the Limelight: GitHub - frcteam195/limelight_vision_node

One of the advantages of ROS that’s lost in a NetworkTables setup is the flexibility topics provide with hooking up new sources of data or replacing where the data is coming from. I noticed this year when adding apriltag functionality, it was not very elegant to add to the NetworkTables → ROS bridge I had. It’s a very manual (and error prone) process.

Team 88 has committed to using Java for the foreseeable future for many reasons and it makes sense for how they operate. So, I started investigating ways to get ROS into that environment. Turns out there’s a pure Java implementation of ROS: rosjava · GitHub
It’s not been updated since ROS kinetic (~5 years) but it still works. A feature I really wanted was the ability to add custom messages. You can do a lot with the standard set, but a lot of what makes ROS work for 88 is the ability to add custom messages. With the help of docker, that works too!

Here’s the setup:

  • Installation dependencies are downloaded using maven: DiffyJrROS/build.gradle at 44ecfd1780d1295d19fcac683f54f8d1f2f9599f · frc-88/DiffyJrROS · GitHub
  • Custom messages are built using docker and set as a local .jar (I’ll explain later): DiffyJrROS/docker at rosjava · frc-88/DiffyJrROS · GitHub
  • Setup the ROS node in the RobotContainer: DiffyJrROS/RobotContainer.java at 44ecfd1780d1295d19fcac683f54f8d1f2f9599f · frc-88/DiffyJrROS · GitHub
  • Create a manager that converts between ROS messages and WPILib+custom objects: DiffyJrROS/TJ2RosCommNode.java at rosjava · frc-88/DiffyJrROS · GitHub

So now instead of a small subset of topics being piped through the NetworkTables bottleneck (in terms of framework elegance), the RIO can access any topic that has messages it can interpret.
Let’s say my team decides to add indoor GPS (if that’s ever FIRST legal) but the sensors only work on the Jetson. A new node can be written for the Jetson that broadcasts the data over a new topic and the RIO can access it directly. The biggest pain with the NetworkTables interface was adding named entries or values of variable length wasn’t very elegant. There are array types for NetworkTables, but if your data structure needs multiple types, you need to create a new entry. It’s just extra plumbing and error checking that is not necessary with this ROS Java setup.
Another hypothetical. Say we want to use ROS as a global path planner but find WPI’s Ramsete controller works much better than the local planners ROS offers. ROS already publishes a global plan on a specific topic. The rio can subscribe to this topic directly and start running the Ramsete controller on it.

In regards to performance, I’ve noticed no difference in latency issues. I have a ping setup that sends a timestamp to the RIO and back to ROS in both the NetworkTables and ROS Java setups. This gets me the round-trip latency. I found in both setups, the latency was ~0.02…0.04 seconds. This lines up with the update rate of RIO and with other messaging protocols I’ve tried. They’ve all been bottlenecked by the 50 Hz update rate of the RIO.

Some caviates:

  • There’s no TF tree broadcaster or listener. To work around this, I have a node on the Jetson that “compacts” the TF tree down to the transforms the team is interested in and publishes them on a separate topic that the rio can access. This is still more flexible than before since I only need to change a text file to include the transform names I want.
  • This may not work on the RIO 1. I was testing this code on a unique chassis that requires a state space controller to function. This increases the memory requirements beyond what the average team needs. This plus ROS puts the Java program very near the memory limits of the RIO. I had to delete some commands and subsystems that were idle to make this run without running out of memory. This will not be an issue on the RIO 2. If anyone has suggestions on how to decrease the base usage of the RIO, I’m all ears. I found that with nothing running, the RIO has ~50 Mb of 250 Mb free. If there’s a way to reclaim some of that 200 Mb, that’ll make this issue go away.

Building custom messages with Docker:
In order to build custom messages, rosjava needs to be installed on the host machine. The latest rosjava only works on kinetic which was for Ubuntu 16. So, I created a Docker file that downloads a ROS kinetic image, installs rosjava, and builds the requested custom messages.
I have only tested this on Ubuntu 20. I’ll likely test this on Windows at some point. If anyone tries it before me, let me know what issues you encounter.
The build steps are:

  • Download tj2_ros to your home folder (GitHub - frc-88/tj2_ros). This can be skipped if you modify the script in the next step.
  • Execute the genjava.sh script: DiffyJrROS/genjava.sh at rosjava · frc-88/DiffyJrROS · GitHub
    • this copies the custom messages from tj2_ros into a nearby folder. This script can easily be modified to point to a different directory.
    • If the script succeeded, it will have copied a file called tj2_interfaces_msgs.jar into the libs/ folder
  • Rebuild the Java project

I think this will open the door to more powerful interactions with ROS. Unfortunately, it’s too late in the season for 88 to test this on the field, so we’ll be trying it in our off season.

beb:

The biggest pain with the NetworkTables interface was adding named entries or values of variable length wasn’t very elegant. There are array types for NetworkTables, but if your data structure needs multiple types, you need to create a new entry. It’s just extra plumbing and error checking that is not necessary with this ROS Java setup.

Yes, lack of support for structured data types in NT has been an increasingly painful limitation that we hope to fix in the future. NT supports raw values, so it’s possible to encode/transport arbitrary encoded data (MessagePack, protobuf, flatbuffers, etc), but there’s no built-in support for autogenerating serialization ala ROS messages. I’m hopeful that we can get a solution integrated for next year so a team can just insert e.g. flatbuffer message declaration files in their codebase and almost everything is generated for them.

beb:

If anyone has suggestions on how to decrease the base usage of the RIO, I’m all ears. I found that with nothing running, the RIO has ~50 Mb of 250 Mb free.

That’s probably understated a bit–were you looking at “free” memory or “available” memory? Linux does a fair amount of caching so “free” memory isn’t representative of available memory on the system. See my post here for a couple of unsupported techniques for freeing up more RAM: Fatal Robot Code Crash - #44 by Peter_Johnson

That’s exciting to hear! I tried to utilize ROS’s serialization and NT’s raw values here: GitHub - frc-88/DiffyJrROS at rosjava-ntbridge
I was running into all sorts of headaches with trying to separate the serialization from the rest of the rosjava library.

I will report back later with what number from free -m I was looking at exactly.

So the actual available memory in the first table is 133 MB. Buffers/cache can be freed at any time by the OS to make room for application needs (see linux - Meaning of the buffers/cache line in the output of free - Server Fault).

Re: free memory on the first line, the adage goes “free memory is wasted memory”. The OS fills free memory with buffers and cache unless it’s needed by applications.

Is there a way to list processes by memory usage on the rio?

It’s imperfect, but something like

for pid in `ps a |cut -c 1-6`; do echo $pid && cat /proc/$pid/cmdline && echo && grep VmRSS /proc/$pid/status; done

gives RSS by PID, and prints the cmdline right before. This could be further cleaned up.

Rosserial using python for anything to the arduino from ROS which is really great. And no Java for the roborio side but c++ would be better probably. I use this alot for making small Atmel microcontroller sensor packages. Normally on a Jetson nano I just use more USB ports before going to the single uart line. Obviously the Rio is not a Jetson so this idea isn’t as viable and this would require a full Ros install in the Rio which is never gonna happen.

So things that worked well is not thinking about the bandwidth but instead limiting how much info you really need to be sending back to the Rio. Treat the Rio like a microcontroller.

  • All non-essential code is moved to the Jetson nano
  • Motor Controllers should just get a position target, velocity target or other preset target from a dedicated and simple Ros topic
  • You can still read sensor data on the roborio and handle some sensor fusions tasks before sending the data to ROS and vise-versa
  • By not sending all of the data both ways you can pick and choose what you care about
  • Sending 1 custom Json message with motor1vel-motor4vel is good enough for the RoboRio especially if you have dedicated lines for stops and leave the default safety controls from FIRST alone.
  • You still use cmd_vel and everything else standard from ROS on the Jetson Nano and can use c++ or your call to handle everything else.
  • This method also works for light duty work on a raspberry pi

To answer the question about the overhead and bandwidth if it’s still limited you could breakout other methods to send basic spi, i2c or other methods to/from the roborio to multiple arduinos. That’s still way messier than I’d like.

The biggest plus was the students can write code in small little Arduino firmware modules instead of having to think about the larger Ros system structure. Each little arduino could be tasked and programmed for a single subsystem if you wanted to get that granular.
